questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following organisms is least likely to be associated with malignancies?
questions.explanation:
HPV 6 and 11 are considered low-risk subtypes and are associated mainly with genital 
warts (condyloma acuminata) and respiratory papillomatosis in both genders. HPV 16 and 18 are considered high-risk subtypes and are associated with cancer cervix and 
pre-cancerous cervical lesions. There is also evidence linking HPV 16 and 18 with cancers of the 342 
Sold by @itachibot anus, vulva, vagina, penis, and oropharynx. Important agents associated with malignant conditions: • HHV-8 (mainly), cytomegalovirus - Kaposi’s sarcoma • Epstein-Barr virus - Burkitt’s lymphoma and nasopharyngeal carcinoma • HPV 16 and 18 - Cancer cervix • HBV and HCV - Hepatocellular carcinoma • Schistosoma - Bladder carcinoma

questions.question:
Question 2: Which among the following is not a primary method of prevention of carcinoma in the 
population?
questions.explanation:
Screening for cancer is a secondary level of prevention. This is because it detects the disease at a pre-invasive or pre-malignant stage when the process of 
carcinogenesis has already started. It thereby aids in further treatment and improved survival. Immunization, restricting the use of tobacco and avoiding alcohol are primary levels of prevention 
because they prevent the start of carcinogenesis.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following women is not at an increased risk of developing breast cancer in 
future? 337 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: A woman who attained menarche at 9 years of age
options.b: A woman who has never breastfed in her lifetime
options.c: A woman who attained menopause at 56 years of age
options.d: A woman who had her first full term pregnancy at 26 years of age

questions.explanation:
Women who have their first full-term pregnancy after 30 years of age are at increased risk for 
breast cancer. The risk of breast cancer increases with an increase in duration of exposure to estrogen. As 
progesterone levels are increased during pregnancy, it reduces the risks of conditions that occur 
due to hyperestrogenemia. 343 
Sold by @itachibot Risk factors for breast cancer: • Modifiable risk factors: • Age at first live birth (First full-term pregnancy after 30 years) • Parity • Lack of breastfeeding • Obesity • Alcohol consumption • Tobacco smoking • Use of hormone replacement therapy • Decreased physical activity • Non-modifiable risk factors: • Increasing age • Early age at menarche (onset of menses before 12 years of age) • Menstrual factors • Female sex • Older age at menopause (onset beyond 55 years of age) • Nulliparity • Race, ethnicity • Genetic predisposition • Family history • History of radiation exposure

questions.question:
Question 5: A 50-year-old woman is at increased risk of breast cancer as she is on hormone replacement 
therapy. Which of the following is the most sensitive method of screening for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Mammography is the most sensitive and specific investigation for detecting breast cancer. It can detect even small tumors that are missed during a self-breast examination, clinical 
examination by the physician and ultrasonographic examination.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following is the best level of prevention of breast cancer?
questions.explanation:
Early diagnosis and treatment is the best level of prevention of breast cancer. It is a secondary 
level of prevention. The earlier a disease is diagnosed and treated, the better is the prognosis. The occurrence of 
secondary cases or any long term disability can be prevented. This is of particular importance 
in chronic diseases. 344 
Sold by @itachibot Early diagnosis and treatment is not as effective and economical as primary prevention. However, 
it may be critically important in reducing the high morbidity and mortality in diseases such as 
essential hypertension, cancer cervix and breast cancer.

questions.question:
Question 7: A patient with Prader-Willi syndrome needs to be evaluated for obesity but the scale for 
measuring height in your clinic is broken. Which of the following indices can you still use in 
this situation?
questions.explanation:
The corpulence index can be used in this scenario as it is independent of height. The formula for 
corpulence index is actual weight/ desired weight.

height in metres?
questions.explanation:
Quetelet's index (Body Mass Index) is obtained by dividing weight in kg by square of height in 
metres.

questions.question:
Question 9: The BMI of two Indian college students are 17 and 24.99 respectively. How will you classify 
them in terms of their BMI?
questions.explanation:
An adult Indian with a BMI of 17 is classified as underweight and a BMI of 24.99 is classified 
as overweight.

questions.question: Question 10: The weight of a diabetic woman is 75 kg and her height is 150 cm. Calculate her BMI.
questions.explanation:
The BMI of an individual with a weight of 75 kg and height of 150 cm is 33. It is calculated as 
follows, BMI = Weight (in kg) / Height2 (in metre2) = 75 / (1.5)2 = 33.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding waist circumference?

options.a: The cut-off for normal waist circumference in Indian women is 90 cm
options.b: It is measured at the midpoint between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest
options.c: It is an approximate index of intra-abdominal and total body fat
options.d: It is an indicator of the risk of chronic diseases

questions.explanation:
The cut-off value for normal waist circumference in Indian women is 80cm, while in Indian men 
it is 90cm. Waist circumference is an approximate indicator of intra-abdominal and total body fat. It is 
measured at the midpoint between the lower border of the rib cage and the iliac crest. It is an 
indicator of the risk of chronic diseases. The cut-off for normal waist circumference is: Categ

questions.question: Question 13: According to the WHO, what is the cut-off for visual acuity for blindness?
questions.explanation:
According to the WHO, blindness is defined as visual acuity of less than 3/60, or a corresponding 
visual field loss to less than 10°, in the better eye with the best possible correction.

questions.question:
Question 15: You administer vitamin A prophylactically to a 15-month-old child during a routine checkup. 
What is the level of prevention being achieved here?
questions.explanation:
Prophylactic administration of vitamin A to a normal child is an example of primary level of 
prevention. It is done to prevent xerophthalmia.

questions.question:
Question 16: A boy is brought to the ophthalmologist with complaints of dryness in both the eyes and 
difficulty in reading. On examination, his eye appears as shown in the below image. What is 
the stage of xerophthalmia according to WHO?
questions.explanation:
The finding in the given image is a Bitot's spot. It belongs to WHO class š1 B of vitamin A 
deficiency.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 2-year-old child on examination shows signs of vitamin A deficiency. What is the dose of 
vitamin A to be administered to this child?
questions.explanation:
2 lakh IU of vitamin A should be administered to a 2-year-old child with vitamin A deficiency. Dosage of vitamin A in children: • 50,000 IU for children less than 6 months of age • 1 lakh IU for children between 6 months to 12 months of age • 2 lakh IU for children above 12 months of age. These doses of vitamin A are to be administered on days 1, 2 and 14 for the treatment of vitamin A 
deficiency.
